general_feedback: Easy and convenient

challenge_feedback: I think an Image Captcha challenge is way faster for users.
Not really, for example "puzzle captchas" are more tolerable than this, but this is still way better than Google's "Click on an image and wait for ages until the next one appears"
No, as it takes significantly longer to solve and might be a problem for websites in languages I don't or barely speak (but otherwise could easily use using some translate feature)
general_feedback: The meaning of the words was very similar in some sentences making it redundant. I feel like I could easily attack a system like this with creating a small statistical model on a huge corpus of data.

challenge_feedback: No. I think this challenge is more time-consuming
No really, as it takes more time than an image-captcha would.
No. Image Captcha is likely faster.
Not quite. In this semantic challenge it can be very easy to fail it by mistake (one wrong click?)
general_feedback: Selection of focal words for the challenge might be problematic. 1. Some speakers may be unfamiliar with some words or some senses. 2. How many words have enough senses and shades of meaning to be useful?

challenge_feedback: I already have to solve many more captchas than I'd like -- but at least many of the image ones tend to be fairly quick to solve. Comparing words in several long-ish sentences seems like it would take even more time and energy.
Yes - it was more fun! But, then, I am a linguist.

general_feedback: May be it is more convenient to classify if two sentences have the same meaning or not

I like image captcha because it's a simple matter of clicking. This one is arguably harder for the human (and perhaps not even for the machine). The other "issue" is that in the example I had ("record") there were clearly two different senses (thing to put music on; thing to keep track of other things) and ranking them doesn't really really make sense -- it's more of a "put it in the correct box" type of deal

challenge_feedback: Image Captcha requires much less mental effort

Not sure, I would be unsure if it's the correct solution with so many items. For me it's fun but you have to think more than with a regular captcha. I would have put the convenience for myself higher but because it's not as accessible for non-English speakers etc. I lowered the score.
general_feedback: Maybe give a correct ordering as an example to illustrate the idea of semantic similarity

challenge_feedback: sure :)But yes, a little shorter would certainly be more agreeable.
general_feedback: I'm wondering if non-linguists would be a bit squeamish about the instructions to judge similarity in meaning. But maybe I underestimate non-linguists' eagerness to engage with semantics. I guess you'll find out!

challenge_feedback: This task definitely requires more thinking than image-captcha.

general_feedback: How useful is your captcha, given a person with very low linguistic knowledge or bad english trying to access data, what if he gets some part of the order wrong, given that deciding the order is highly subjective.Very close meanings can be misinterpreted and will take multiple attempts for the user to just get to the single gold result unlike the image-captchas which will only require common-sense.

challenge_feedback: No, because Image-Captcha is much quicker to fulfill and semantic similarity depends highly on language proficiency and is very subjective
general_feedback: What to do with sentences that I would rate on the same level?

challenge_feedback: Depends massively on the amount of answers needed to complete the captcha, but if it's only one answer then yes.

general_feedback: The challenge is very time consuming compared to an image-captcha. Some users could be annoyed by that

challenge_feedback: no. It takes more cognitive effort than image-captchas.
personally no, but it makes sense to have non-image captchas!
The sentences were quite difficult to understand, I am not sure they were the best examples for this task. However, I think it could be useful in the future with more suitable examples.
general_feedback: The first screen was a bit too crowded and full of typos. As a senior in the field, I'd advise you proofread everything :)
I think sentence meaning order is not good for people that have dyslexia or any other type of  reading disorder, instead images are universal.

challenge_feedback: It depends on the language. If the semantic captcha is not in my native language, I would prefer the image captcha. If the sentence is in my native language, I would have no preference (maybe the time it takes me to solve the corresponding captcha).
general_feedback: It wasn't really possible to order the sentences that didn't have a similar meaning (I'm not sure if this was intentional).

challenge_feedback: no, ordinary captcha are easier and less ambiguous
rather not, because in comparison to Image-Captcha it takes more effort and time.
it seems like it took longer to complete than the image or math-based captcha

general_feedback: No

challenge_feedback: Probably not. The similarity scale is not particularly well defined, so what is a 2 for one person might be a 3 for another even if they understand the sentences the same way. It might work if the response time and cursor movement are taken into account, though.

general_feedback: The manual ordering interface is annoying. Please consider developing alternative input methods

challenge_feedback: For me it's okay, but in general not because you need good knowledge in the language to complete the captcha.
No, because this kind of test is more time consuming
depending on how many sentences one has to evaluate, this approach could be preferable to image captchas, that can somnetimes be a bit unclear.
general_feedback: both examples should be full sentences, otherwise it can get confusing to parse the sentence-snippets.

challenge_feedback: Yes, but with a possible choice of language.

general_feedback: Good luck!
It excludes too many people - those who do not speak the language good enough.

challenge_feedback: Not really. I think we are in a phase where Captchas are only being (mis)used for cheap data labeling.
general_feedback: Asking for an absolute ordering may be too much, when there are multiple sentences that are not related at all. This will probably introduce noise in your study.

challenge_feedback: While it would be more fun and I personally might prefer it because of that, I think anyone who has less than near-native proficiency in English would not be able to complete the challenge and thus others might not prefer it.
general_feedback: I think the idea is fun, but the idea of testing if one's a human by testing one's semantic understanding in English is something I find quite problematic. It assumes that every user would be proficient enough to answer the test seeing as it requires near-native proficiency to understand the examples, which is not the case for a lot of people, and particularly disparaging towards non-native speakers coming from a minority background. It is also implied that there is (only) one correct answer to this test, which is never really the case when it comes to  semantics, as people might have different conceptualisations of meaning based on their previous knowledge and how knowledge is mapped and linked in the brain. It might be good to read up on cognitive linguistics/semantics for this study.

challenge_feedback: No (it may be more time consuming and may be difficult for many people)

general_feedback: I'm sorry but this very impractical. 1) it takes a lot of time fot a captcha 2) it is quite hard to establish a ground truth for this task, we are talking about fine-grained semantics! 3) it is clearly aimed at native speakers only
It's not really clear how "similar" the words "bar" in "sitting at the bar" and in "bar mirror" are. For a human.

challenge_feedback: No, because I could understand image captchas and solve them much faster than the proposed Semantic NLP catches. Because we humans see faster than we read. Compared to the typical scenarios in image captchas, which are rather trivial, like spotting the traffic light, I found the topic here quite abstract, making ordering difficult. Maybe only selecting matching sentences so the given reference sentence.

general_feedback: no

challenge_feedback: Being a text researcher, yes, of course. Others might not.
general_feedback: I hate captchas in general :)
to intellectual task for captcha

challenge_feedback: This is probably more demanding than captcha, probably also fuzzier as much as I can imagine how it works.
general_feedback: The survey would be much more trustworthy if there was some more specific information as to who and why conducts it."How convenient and practical do you think is such type of "human-detection" challenge in daily life?" contains two questions, as convenient and practical have different (even if related) meanings

challenge_feedback: It seems a bit slower to perform than a typical captcha (text or puzzle), but quicker than an image-captcha.

general_feedback: With 1-2 items, the context seemed very restricted (maybe too restricted to even judge the exact meaning of that instance). I would have liked to get more information on what exactly you were looking for in terms of similarity, assuming there's one ideal solution. Is 'record' inside a compound like 'record label' the same as a specific record, or less similar to playing a record than a specific record (if so, on what grounds)?

challenge_feedback: More or less on the same level

general_feedback: It does not feel fair for people without any English knowledge of speakers of minority languages

challenge_feedback: I would prefer Image-Captcha because images in general are more straightforward than texts.

general_feedback: Many people would not be able to understand what to do.

challenge_feedback: No. I don't like Captchas. They are annoying and routinely used for purposes others than their stated one, i.e. identification - e.g. machine learning training.
I am not sure if I would prefer the textual captcha, because it has too much ambiguity and requires more thinking.
No, it can be ableist under certain contexts and disadvantage speakers of dialects
general_feedback: N/A, very interesting

challenge_feedback: Depends on the difficulty. The sentences in this survey were easy to label, however, if they are more complicated and require re-reading multiple times, then I'd rather use an image captcha

general_feedback: No

challenge_feedback: No, images are still easier to get the gist of it and they are faster to solve as the visual apparatus functions faster then the reading one
general_feedback: :D

challenge_feedback: No, this felt like a lot more effort than an image captcha, which feels a lot more intuitive.
general_feedback: I feel like it could work with if: 1. the instructions were refined to be more intuitive. E.g. "Click on all traffic lights" is much quicker to grasp than "re-rank the sentences based on semantic similarity of the highlighted word" (paraphrasing here, but I think you get what I mean :) )2. Maybe multiple pair-wise comparisons would be more intuitive (e.g. in which one of these two sentences the highlighted word is closer to the reference). Not sure if that would have the same robustness though.3. Bit of a side-note, but have you tried giving this task to an LLM? Would be curios to know how it compares
Nice sentences:)

I didn’t understand the first two sentences, so my rating was basically a random guess. If implemented, it should make sure that a proficient speaker understands the sentences. Also, I found it annoying that the same 2nd sentence was repeated every time.

challenge_feedback: This very much depends on the presentation and number of sentences required to solve this task: Parallel image processing is quite easy for humans. With text however, one needs to at least skim all of the sentences in order to make a (I imagine) quite noisy decision.
I think it would be difficult for people with language, reading and communication disorders. It may also be complicated for people without high education. Image-Captcha are more accessible.
general_feedback: It would be nice if people could choose what kind of Captcha they prefer, to avoid accessibility issues.

challenge_feedback: I'd like it because it's something else for a change. But I'm rather steeped in linguistics, might be hard to understand for people who are not.
It's better than the counting challenges with a timer, for sure, but would be challenging for non-native speakers or people with some cognitive disability.
general_feedback: I don't know if this was on purpose, but while almost all the sentences were easy to understand, the one about poetry sales records being tuned was very confusing.

challenge_feedback: No, because it require more knowledge in the language of interest. But it might be a good alternative for visually-disabled people (using screen readers).
general_feedback: Maybe I have overread it, but maybe emphasize in the instructions more that you are interested in the meaning of the words in bold-face and not the sentences in general. My ratings refer to a meaning comparison of the wohle sentence. I just understood to rate the bold-face words when I saw the question on the general information page.

challenge_feedback: Probably not. I found the captcha challenged quite difficult. You need quite a fundamental understanding of the English language to know all semantic nuances of a word regarding it's context
general_feedback: Quite an interesting approach. However, it might not feasible to use as not every user is so fluid in the English language

challenge_feedback: Depends on the difficulty, but text captcha might be better, especially for visually impaired people
general_feedback: Good idea but I think the example is weird/difficult

challenge_feedback: No, image is more convenient for me as you can easily spot patterns / objects and there is no need to read through sentences. Also images are more language-independent.
general_feedback: A short introduction on what a Captcha-challenge is would have been nice. But apart from this the study was great!

challenge_feedback: Yes, but it would be less universal than current captcha challenges.
I might prefer this one, but drag-and-drop is not convenient for me, clicking would be easier. Then what happens if our language profeciency is not good enough?
general_feedback: Good luck with the thesis and the study!

challenge_feedback: Ideally if I was able to discern the meaning of the sentences I would prefer it over image CAPTCHAs, however I struggled with the sentences given in the test because I did not know the meaning of most usages and had to guess.
Yes, maybe. Sometimes the pictures used in Image-Captcha-challenges are very difficult to 'read'.
